items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: In the News] C.H.A.M.P. members in the News
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. members in the News
items.htmlBody:
Check out C.H.A.M.P. member Amanda Dyes work with Worcesters Mushroom Urban Farm Initiative inMargaret LaRouxs article:Little Champions (https://lane-press.mydigitalpublication.com/publication/?i=851847&p=34&view=issueViewer)

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.htmlBody:
Hello mushroom lovers,

We had a marvelous tour of BOSLab, the countrys first community biolab. C.H.A.M.P. members learned about opportunities for using equipment such as PCR thermal cyclers, fluorescence plate readers, incubators, and autoclaves. We discussed the possibilities for DNA barcoding/IT tagging, advanced microscopy, and a range of other art and bio-engineering projects.

We also exploredcreatingC.H.A.M.P./BOSLabco-branded workshops, including sessions on cultivating mushrooms, hosting a crash course on microscopy and staining, and presenting talks and film screenings.

Lastly, we touched on outdoor programming such as using Lil Laba laboratory on wheels for conducting science au plein air!

If any of this excites you, send your thoughts to the C.H.A.M.P. suggestion box!

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/

Dr. Wendy Pouliot, neurobiologist and BOSLab President, with the 1940s windshield-wiper display cabinet she converted into Lil Lab, a mobile research station outfitted with a trinocular stereo microscope. Underwritten by grants from the Massachusetts Cultural Council.

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.subject: Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.htmlBody:
Hello Mushroom Lover!

Im excited to invite you to an in-person, on-site visit to BOSLabs (https://www.boslab.org/projects), a nonprofit community laboratory that makes cutting-edge biology hands-on and accessible to curious people outside traditional academia. If youre interested in fungi, this is a rare chance to see how tools like DNA sequencing, yeast engineering, imaging, and biochemistry can be used to identify, grow, study, and even design biological systemssometimes in delightfully unexpected ways (theyve even experimented with synthesizing truffle flavor in a lab). BOSLabs supports open, lay science: teaching, experimentation, and creative exploration across biology, chemistry, genetics, and bioengineering.


The on-site visit will take place on Friday, January 9, between noon and 7 pm (time to be determined). There will also be a virtual online open house happening tonight at 7 PM. RSVP here for virtual open house:


https://meetu.ps/e/PzDLC/B3jBy/i


If youre interested in the in-person visit, please email me with the times youd be available this Friday between noon and 7 pm, and Ill confirm the time that works for the greatest number of people.


Thx,

Jon Applefield

items.subject: Ari - Project Idea
items.htmlBody:
Happy New Year to all
Here is a description of a possible project that CHAMP can take on. 
This is just an outline. It does not include technicalities. I can provide the technical methodology if a consensus is reached. 
The project entails placing a network of synchronized (programmable) LED lights under the surface of water. For example, Duckpond, at Boston Public Garden, this is where the Swan boats are. In the winter the pond is un-utilized. Procedurally, the LED-network will be installed in the pond before it freezes. When the pond does eventually freeze over, it will create the proper conditions to deliver an immersive, colorful light show, with images that appear emanating through the ice. The subject matter can widely vary, and include fungi with associated culturally-themed characters. This can also be set to sound affects. Funding for the project can be through the Mass Cultural Council. Or, directly from the city of Boston Art Commission.

                         Ari 

                Ari Stamatiou 
         Plimira@comcast.net
                617-962-8550

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P.s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P.s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.htmlBody:
Report from C.H.A.M.P.s 1st Foray, Lincoln, MA 12.7.25

Larry started off saying something about the importance of noticing what we dont see, but the presence of negative data couldnt hold a candle to what materialized 10 minutes later: Bulgaria inquinans, commonly called Black Bulgar or Bachelors Buttons bulbous protrusions like gobs of tar emerging from huge sawn logs oak, I believe. Matte black, like Finnish licorice, with cup-like depressions. I mistakenly thought the name had something to do with the former Soviet country, Bulgaria, but etymology filled the binomial with color and motion: inflated, blister-like; dirtying, polluting, blackening, staining, making unclean. So be it - the dirty, bulging fungi left me feeling renewed. Larrys words and our presence as a group in the woods Jula, his Dad, Martin, and son Micha; Dan, Liam, Sean, KieuLy, Larry, and myself amplified a simple message: even on a chilly, steel-grey New England morning, the forest floor holds a cache of little treasures like Hanukkah gelt or Christmas cookies cups, crusts, and jellies, resplendent in a quiet but full-throated way, edging out the inelegant rumble of the MBTA commuter rail trundling by. Arboreal chamber music enjoyed from front-row seats, reminding me of John Cage, amateur mycologist and vanguard creator of aleatory music: There is no such thing as an empty space or an empty time. There is always something to see, something to hear. In fact, try as we may to make a silence, we cannot.

A quick rundown of notable species seen: a cascade of lumpy polypores Trametes gibbosa; oak-log sections tinted with green wood-staining fungus Chlorociboria sp.; tiny matchstick fungi Phaeocalicium polyporaeum lifting off from the margins of purple-tooth polypores Trichaptum abietinum; and, as if bidding us farewell like tiny munchkins from Oz, a hairy fairy Lachnum virgineum; and a troupe of Mycena sp.

On the Horizon

Stay tuned for our next events. Plans are underfoot for a movie night pegged to an ethnographic film.

M

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Reminder: Larry Millmans walk @ 11 AM Sunday
items.subject: Reminder: Larry Millmans walk @ 11 AM Sunday
items.htmlBody:
Not all fungi head to Florida for the winter!RSVP.

JoinLarry Millman@Codman Woods - Lincoln, MA. Sunday @ 11:00 AM. Parking at Donelan's Supermarket - 145 Lincoln Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

C.H.A.M.P.Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] THE NEWS FEED IS NOW WORKING!
items.subject: THE NEWS FEED IS NOW WORKING!
items.htmlBody:
Simply email <comm.hub.myco@gmail.com> anything newsworthy! Include "[CHAMP: News]" in the subject line to automatically post the email on the CHAMP website's news feed. Keep the rest of the group up to date with ease!

-Cody
